title: ‘Evil’ woman who posed online as missing toddler spared jail
text:
Heidi Robinson made a fake profile pretending to be a toddler who vanished on her second birthday almost 40 years ago (Picture: Mercury Press)

A woman who made a fake Facebook profile pretending to be a missing toddler was suffering from a mental illness when she committed the act of ‘unimaginable cruelty’, a judge ruled today.

Heidi Robinson, 40, has been spared jail for pretending to be Katrice Lee, who vanished on her second birthday on November 28 in 1981.

District Judge Nicholas Sanders said he was satisfied Robinson ‘developed an honestly held belief’ she was Katrice, and handed her an 18-week prison sentence suspended for two years.

Speaking outside of court, the missing toddler’s father said he thought Robinson had ‘got away very lightly’ and called her an ‘evil and wicked troll’.

Katrice went missing 37 years ago on the outskirts of Paderborn in Germany, near the British military base where her father Richard Lee was stationed.

At the sentencing hearing on Wednesday, Wirral Magistrates Court heard Robinson, from Merseyside, sent a Facebook friend request in August last year to Katrice’s sister Natasha Walker.

A judge said Heidi Robinson genuinely believed she was the missing toddler due to mental illness (Picture: Mercury Press)

Richard Lee, Katrice’s father, said Robinson got off lightly and called her an ‘evil troll’ (Picture: Mercury Press)

Mrs Walker messaged the profile, which included photos of Katrice and her family, and asked for it to be removed before contacting military police who are investigating her sister’s disappearance.

Robinson underwent a DNA test which proved she was not Katrice, but still continued to hound Mrs Walker, accusing her of a cover up and saying she should be investigated.

The court heard how Mrs Walker’s wedding day was ‘ruined’ by the stress brought on by Robinson’s actions.

In a statement, Mrs Walker said she ‘felt sick to the pit of my stomach’ when she saw the fake account.

She said: ‘We are going through a living hell and we don’t need anything else adding in.’

Katrice, who would have been 40 this year, was with her mother at a supermarket when she went missing.

Last month officers arrested a man in connection over her disappearance and searched a terraced house in Swindon, Wiltshire, but he was released without charge.

Katrice Lee, who went missing as a toddler 37-years-ago on November 28, from a shopping centre in Germany Picture: North News)

In a statement addressing Robinson, Katrice’s father said: ‘For you this saga may end here. ‘My family do not have that luxury.

‘Our nightmare continues, you cannot see the wounds that you have inflicted, but the scars you have left run deep.’

Robinson pleaded guilty earlier this month to using a public communications network to send a message that was grossly offensive, indecent or menacing on November 3 last year.

Ember-Jade Wong, defending Robinson, said: ‘She had no understanding as to what her offending was, given her condition at the time, believing up until very recently, when she became fitter, that she was Katrice Lee.’

On top of her suspended sentence, Robinson must have mental health treatment for 12 months and carry out rehabilitation activity for 40 days.

She was also ordered to pay £500 compensation to Mrs Walker, given a restraining order to stop her contacting the Lee family and issued with a nighttime curfew.

Judge Sanders said: ‘I’m satisfied, based on reports, that you had developed an honestly held belief which I have to accept is hard to understand to people not suffering from it, that you were Katrice Lee.’
